subject: Re: Quickscript letters
msgSnippet: I ve been using QS for a long time and I also like the idea that you can hear the accent of the writer. I ve corrisponded with a few people from this group and
messageBody:
I've been using QS for a long time and I also like the idea that you
can hear the accent of the writer. I've corrisponded with a few people
from this group and our spelling of some words do not match up. Even
writers who are both from the U.S. will have different ways of
representing their speech.

There's been some long posting of the "correct" way to write something
in QS but most times that's just correct for that writer's accent.

Speaking of "writing", I've mentioned this before, it's the reading of
QS that will really help you learn it. If anyone wants to do some
postal mail correspondance to work with QS I'd be happy to be a part of
it.

Chuck Peck

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Andii Bowsher <andii@o...> wrote:
>
> Hi Benjamin,
> I'm a Brit and a fan of dialect. I gather that the idea is to agree a
> dialect of Engish to use but I reckon that is going to be hard to do;
so
> many folk like yourself don't want to have to learn a new accent to
> write with! I have corresponded QS-wise with people from the USA and
New
> Zealand who just write as they talk. It takes a little getting used to
> but in principle is no different to speech, in fact I liked 'hearing'
> their accents as I read. More human somehow....
> -Andii
>
